III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• The facility was provided consultation on reviewing the contract the facility has
with MDHHS to ensure they are completing all assessments required per the
contract.

V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The facility was provided consultation regarding scheduling a fire inspection as
soon as possible following LARA approving the plans.
• The facility was provided consultation regarding reaching out to contracts to
discuss the number of beds the facility is contracted with MDHHS.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: During the
period under review there has not been any special investigations.
The facility has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period and is in compliance with the CAP as follows: The CAP was in
response to the 2022 Interim Inspection dated October 6, 2022, where the facility
was found in non-compliance for rules 400.4113(b) Employee records, and rule
400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers. A CAP was
approved on October 21, 2022, and was effective as the violations were not
repeated during this inspection.
The facility continues to have a variance through November 15, 2023, for Rule
400.527(1): Sprinkler system. The facility has made significant progress as the
facility construction has been completed, the dry system is installed and
functioning, the new fire panel has been installed and is functioning properly, the
water pump and fire suppression system is functioning correctly. Great Lakes
Recovery Center has submitted MDHHS forms in the LARA system and currently
LARA is requesting the E3 plans that show the alarm panel diagram and plans for
the replaced dry fire suppression system. Great Lakes Recovery Center has
obtained the E3 plans and has converted the plans to PDF files to upload into
LARA’s system. Great Lakes Recovery is continuing to work on obtaining the fire
suppression diagram as this was created by the original contractor of the building
development which has been out of business for five years. Once the fire
suppression diagram can be located, this will also be uploaded into the LARA
system and reviewed. Once this occurs, a contractor will schedule a time to visit
the facility to review the repairs and a fire inspection will be completed. The facility
continues to complete fifteen-minute walk through checks of the facility which were
viewed while on site.

Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on a review of the annual
financial report.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator reported the facility has worked to correct rule violations
from the 2022 interim inspection regarding rule 400.4113(b) and rule 400.4114.
The facility has worked to rectify the issues leading to the rule violations found in
the 2022 interim inspection and has a process in place to ensure rule compliance.
Chief Administrator reported the facility continues to make steps in becoming
compliance with the variance for rule 400.4527 (1) Sprinkler System and the
variance has recently been approved through November 15, 2023. The facility will
continue to complete fifteen-minute fire checks throughout the building and
document these checks until the fire inspection is approved with an A rating.
Staff and Youth Interviews
One administrator, one supervisory staff, and two direct care staff were
interviewed at the facility. Staff report feeling safe and supported by upper
management. Staff reported the facility is wonderful to work for and staff feel a
great sense in pride for the work they do to help youth. Communication is a strong
asset at the facility and staff feel there is an open line of communication amongst
one another and with upper management. Staff shared how they are provided
with great training opportunities, and they feel they have all the tools they need to
be successful in their position at the facility.
Three youth were interviewed at the facility. Youth reported feeling safe and
respected by staff. All youth interviewed had wonderful things to say about the
facility including how great the food is, feeling supported by staff, receiving
excellent treatment, and really enjoying being at the facility. Youth did not have
any concerns to report about the facility.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the facility was completed during the onsite visit. The facility
was clean, and no safety concerns were noted. The facility is currently doing
cosmetic work and has recently painted both living areas as well as in the process
of repainting the kitchen/dining room area. Medications and cleaning supplies are
stored appropriately. All bedrooms had appropriate bedding. The kitchen was
clean with the weekly menu posted. The facility had emergency plans posted, the
intent to check criminal history posted in the entry of the facility, and fire
extinguishers were serviced in January 2023. Varying interval check logs not to
exceed fifteen minutes were viewed and appropriate.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes. It is recommended that the agency be issued a renewal of their regular
license.
